} } } Length:: 1:05 MinsI'll be updating this review as I play around with it more, so check for updates!NEW UPDATE!! 11/27/13After a month more of playing around with this camera, I am really really happy with it. Battery life has consistently been around 2 hrs, which should provide you with ample time of recording. Buttons are all still working well, no issues there, the wireless trigger runs pretty well, albeit a little slow. I really cannot complain about this camera, and given my past with GoPro cameras, this is saying a good amount.BUY THIS CAMERA FROM AMAZON, DO NOT BUY FROM GOPRO. I hate giving GoPro money, because they have awful customer service and for a period of two years sent me broken camera after broken camera. However, the footage that you get from these cameras are second to none. Feel free to read my review of the Hero3 (http://www.amazon.com/review/R1RRHRRBEKP0CC/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm) if you want to get a review on that camera and of the company.Have a great holiday season, thanks for reading my review!NEW UPDATE 10/26/13To start off, one common theme of the GoPro cameras throughout their existence is that the video quality has been top notch. Even on the older models where the cameras were much maligned (and rightfully so), nobody could write off the beautiful video that the camera COULD obtain (when it worked). This was the major underlying reason why these cameras were so loved/hated; when they worked, they'd take incredible video, but, they often had many bugs and flaws.The GoPro Hero3 was a SIGNIFICANT upgrade over the hero2 in terms of video quality. I was one of the first to get that camera and couldn't believe how much better the quality was. Not simply in terms of resolution, but light sensitivity, frame rate, depth of field; the video that the camera could record was stunning. However, as I alluded to before, this camera was so full of bugs you could have taught an entomology class on it! To compound issues, GoPro had AWFUL customer service and no ways to resolve the problems that these cameras faced.Enter the Hero3+. In many ways, this camera is very much like its predecessor. While being a little smaller, having the case slimmed down, the guts are almost the same, and the video quality is almost the same too. They have added a "super" mode, which is supposed to produce even better quality video, however I have not seen much of an effect while using it (keep in mind, you have to drop the frame rate to use it). However, they have really fixed a LOT of small issues which make this camera worth the $400.The BIGGEST change they have done on this camera is FIXED THE BATTERY LIFE!!!!!!!!!!!!! The 30% increase is misleading; I would normally only get about 20-30 minutes of recording time on my old hero3, but now with the hero3+, I recored for 2 hours on one battery!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! That's almost a 400% increase! I don't know what they did to increase it so much, but this was one of THE most frustrating aspects of the camera. Now that you can safely record on one battery for the majority of whatever you're doing, you don't have to worry about changing the battery, getting the camera dirty/wet, and fussing with it when you may not be in a good environment to do so (mud/snow/water/dirt...). I have tried many times recording on this camera, and I can say with confidence that the battery life is far far improved.I recently attended the Albuquerque, NM hot air balloon festival, and took some video with the GoPro to demonstrate a few things. While this video may look good, keep in mind that the quality is severely handcuffed since Amazon limits the size to 100mb.1.) The dynamic range of this camera is great. You'll see it capture both light and dark areas extremely well; this was early early morning and there were a ton of shadows as the sun was starting to rise. It did a great job keeping everything evenly lit and balanced.2.) Pronounced fish eye. This is good/bad, because you'll be able to capture a large range of field from the camera's view point, however the edges are very fish eyed.3.) I naturally want to hold the camera on the black frame that houses the lens, however you may see on the video that my finger kinda pops into the frame of the video. BE CAREFUL IF SHOOTING WITH HANDS!! The lens must be set to record everything directly outside of that black frame, so don't put anything near there.4.) Frame rate is great at 1080, but for anything above, it is garbage. It may seem attractive to some people to shoot video in 2.7K and 4K, however you are not going to want to after trying. The frame rate is way to slow to make any jump in resolution worth it. Even these hot air balloons, which rise slowly, still look bad in the 2.7k resolution. 1080 is where it is at.5.) Not sure if this is an isolated occurrence, but 720 does not look good at all. Very grainy, very choppy, and I didn't like the video at all. Stick to 1080.Of note: The camera did freeze on me once, but this only happened once, as compared to dozens of times with the hero3. Not perfect, but a huge improvement.Hope this helps!! I have a lot more video I can upload at a later time, let me know if you have any questions!10/4/13:At first glance, the Hero3+ does not look much different than the Hero3. The packaging is the same, the accompanying accessories are the same, however as the title implied, there are a bunch of small improvements that are of note.1.) The lock button is SIGNIFICANTLY upgraded. For users of the Hero3, this may have been one of the more frustrating aspects of the camera. There was a two step mechanism required to unlock the case, which often got jammed with mud/dirt/debris, and even after rigorous cleaning made for difficult operation. They have improved the lock mechanism to one big bar that flips open without much effort or strain. Much MUCH easier to use, and I'm sure will be MUCH more durable.2.) The buttons controlling the camera are WAY easier to use. I have been a Hero user since the original models, and these two buttons, on the side and on the top, have always been extremely difficult to push/get to respond. This new case/camera has reworked the sensitivity of these buttons and as a result, all you need is a simple push to get the camera to respond. While this may not seem like much, those buttons were such an annoyance previously that this upgrade helps out a LOT.3.) Battery life. If the case lock was not the worst aspect of the Hero3, the battery life was. For an event covering 2 hours, I had to bring 3 batteries and HOPE that they got me through. I brought this camera to the Bills vs. Browns game last night, and recorded a ton of footage with a lot of pictures and the battery didn't drop one bar throughout the entire game!!! THIS IS A HUGE UPGRADE. From other tests that I've done, I have been able to record about two hours of video before the battery died (shooting 1080p 48fps) and I cannot stress enough how big of an improvement this is.4.) New Video modes. As you'll read about in the product description, they have included new "super" video modes for 1080p and 720p. While the video looks good on it, one thing to note is that these "super" modes are unable to be shot at the full FPS that the regular 1080p and 720p modes can handle (1080p can shoot 60fps, at super it is at 48).Overall, GoPro has address the MAJOR critiques to their product and should be commended for this new iteration. While there aren't any new significant additions/features/toys, they have SIGNIFICANTLY improved the existing Hero3, and finally made it worth a $400 investment.

Reviews.Title: Focus issue!!!
Reviews.Author: kwh
Reviews.Content: The depth of field is horrible.  I took a photograph with this camera and everything in the background was out of focus and blurry.  I took a photograph of the same image with my GoPro3 and the depth of field was excellent and everything in the background was clear.

Reviews.Title: Buyer beware. Amazon selling USED, DEFECTIVE cameras
Reviews.Author: WFM3
Reviews.Content: This review is not about the GoPro camera itself but about Amazon's deceitful selling practices.  I bought the GoPro thru Amazon as a Christmas gift.  After several hours of trying to get the Wifi to sync with the GoPro iPhone app, I called GoPro customer service.  The rep told me that the Wifi settings and password had been changed from the default settings so the camera must have been previously owned. I was beyond furious. Amazon sold me a used camera!! I then tested the camera and it was defective (i.e. video would skip) and I also noticed several components missing from the box.  I called Amazon Customer Support and asked to speak to a supervisor.  After 20+ minutes of being on hold and several times being told I was being transferred , the rep finally said a supervisor would call me back.  Im still waiting for the call.I am of course returning the camera but Amazon is NOT the organization I thought they were.  Shame on you Amazon

Reviews.Title: GoPro Hero3 Silver vs. Hero3+ Silver
Reviews.Author: Wayne "Omegafiler"
Reviews.Content: While looking at this new camera, I'm also going to focus on my comparison between the GoPro Hero3 Silver and the new Hero3+ Silver. What's different, how does it work on its own, is it worth an upgrade? Let's find out.OUT OF THE BOXFirst out is the camera, as it's nicely mounted in the glass container at the top of the box. It's already obvious the new housing for the Hero3+ is noticeably smaller and more compact than the older one. The housing buttons are larger and easier to press, but everything else was downsized. The latch no longer requires an extra tab to slide over, yet still feels very secure and tight when closed. The front covering over the lens has become simplified as there are no longer rivets or a large bezel adding to bulk.There is some concern this could reduce durability, but short of throwing it into a wall, I'm going to just base this on look and feel. Which is to say it appear to be just a solid and durable as the old one. Otherwise the camera itself is identical in size to the old one, so everything is interchangeable. Extra batteries and cables will work just fine with both. You can check the product description to see what exactly is included, but it's just the basics. A few basic mounting brackets, stickers, mini-USB cable, etc. No charger is included.CAMERA SETUPAfter charging, the first step will be to supply a micro-sd card. I did run into an issue where my 32GB Sandisk Class 10 card wouldn't work. I just got an Error on the display. Despite manually cleaning and formatting the card to the specific exFat file system the camera required, it was never happy. At least not until I found the menu option within the camera itself to format the card for me (trash can icon). After that, it's been working great.Speaking of the menu, going through the initial setup via the on-board controls is still as annoying as it was in the previous version. In other words, we have the same basic menu layout and 2 buttons to change menus and make your selections. If you've used them before, you're all set. If not, I do suggest going over the user's guide which has a menu layout that'll help you find what you want and avoid getting lost. As this camera has wireless functionality, it's usually best to get this part setup and use your smartphone to connect and make changes.The GoPro Android app, which I'm using on 2 separate phones, worked great. I used my LG G2 and Note 2 so we could test them out separately. There was virtually no difference between the two, other than the additional video modes the Hero3+ added in the drop-down menus. The preview still has a 1-2 second delay, but more than enough as a basic view-finder. Once again, really no change on the software side of things. At least nothing cosmetic.VIDEO QUALITYThis is of course the important part. So for this test I've basically got them mounted side-by-side on the windshield of the car. Both phones were wirelessly connected to the android phones as well we could easily make identical changes on the fly. Testing was done in daylight and in multiple different video modes. You can check Amazon or GoPro's website to see an exact list of video mode changes going to the plus model, but the important ones are some things that have trickled down from the older Black Series.This includes 1080p @ 60hz, 960p @ 60hz, and 720p @ 120hz which is basically double the frame-rate of older GoPro Silver. Whether I was taking advantage of the higher frame rate of the new model, the video quality was noticeable improved. The image was brighter, more vibrant, and seemed to have more detail than the older non-plus model. And once you take advantage of the higher FPS, action shots look considerably smoother.The camera's megapixels have dropped from 11MP to 10MP, although I didn't notice any change in still photo quality.  It's also not something I use all that much with the GoPro. Even though it of course has plenty of features such as burst shot mode.AUDIOWhile playing both videos back to back, it's very obvious there is an improvement in audio quality. We're using the same backing (with 2 openings) while it was in the car. With the older model, our voices and other audio were quiet and muffled. But with the plus, our voice was very clear and easy to understand. The audio was simply more crisp and detailed. Really a night and day difference.CURRENT ISSUE (PENDING RESOLUTION)While in the car, I have the cameras mounted upside down. There is a quick setting in each camera to flip the image vertically. However, the new GP3+ also flipped the image horizontally, something the old one didn't do. This of course creates a very odd perspective as it makes it appear as though you're on the wrong side of the road. This occurred at any resolution where the image had to be flipped to upside down mode. With the free downloadable GoPro video editing software, you can of course manually flip the video horizontally, but it's certainly not ideal.I'm still working with GoPro to find a resolution. We've already swapped out the camera and the new one does the same thing. Will update when I have more info.PROS:+ More compact housing+ Increased battery capacity+ Improved High resolution video quality+ Noticable audio quality improvement+ Higher FPS video recording at all HD resolutions+ Durable and Waterproof (in housing)+ Wireless smartphone connectivity+ Has most important features of older Black seriesCONS:- Battery life could always be better- Menu controls can still be confusing- Slightly expensive- Camera gets very warm- Picky with SD card formatting- Current horizontal flip issue (pending resolution)CONCLUSION:Overall there wasn't much to dislike about the new camera. Considering its intended purpose, I don't think you can really find anything better for the money. The GoPro Hero3+ Silver basically offers many of the improved video quality/FPS of the older Black series, for less money. And other than 4K recording of the new Black series, the Silver series fits into a nice "mid-range" providing everything most folks are looking for. All while making several minor but very welcome design improvements.Bottom line, spend a little more for the new plus model and you won't be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Messed up focus
Reviews.Author: Roller
Reviews.Content: A significant downgrade to my Hero 3 Black, the 3+ Black is out of focus for anything past a few metres. Everything ends up blurry and smeared. Seems the still picture output quality has been downgraded too as file sizes are much smaller suggesting more compression even when everything is in focus (inside a room - no distance focus). So the 3+ Black is great for selfies and useless for everything else. I'm returning mine today

Reviews.Title: GoPro response to infinity focus issue
Reviews.Author: R. Israel
Reviews.Content: With all the comments on poor infinity focus, I wrote to GoPro and highlighted one of the comments here regarding blurry images at infinity and asked for their comment.  Here's what GoPro said:Hi,GoPro has designed the HERO3+ with a new lens to improve focus and sharpness for both video and photos.  The new camera is optimized for improved image clarity at all focal ranges – edges, center, close and distance.  If a customer is experiencing loss of clarity or focus at a distance, this is not an expected outcome.  It's possible that there may have been an issue with the production of that particular camera or that a camera software update is needed.  We will troubleshoot the problem with the customer according to the specific issue that is being experienced and find a resolution.

Reviews.Title: Battery issues - locking up
Reviews.Author: Robert Wambier
Reviews.Content: Ever since I bought this camera, the camera has had power issues.  I have reset the batttery - and the camera comes on.  But when I turn the camera off and try to turn the camera on again....it will not turn on, unless I reset the battery again.  I have read the manual, and I've emailed GoPro several times on this issue.  I believe the camera has a faulty connection in the back.  I don't think it's the SD card - I have a Class 10 MicroSD card that came with it that GoPro has recommended.

Reviews.Title: WARNING: Incompatible with current BacPacs!
Reviews.Author: G. Lee "Addicted shopper"
Reviews.Content: I just received 4 GoPro 3+ Black, and bought 4 LCD BacPacs.  Well, guess what, they are not compatible.  GoPro 3+'s housing is slimmer, more tapered to the camera itself.  I just called GoPro directly and ask them whether they will be releasing any back housing piece to make BacPacs compatible with the new GoPro 3+ housing, and the representative said I need to buy the BacPac Compatible Housing (197' / 60m) for $49.99; which is basically the old GoPro 3 housing.  Talking about design department's brain fart!  I rather just have the old GoPro 3 housing to come with GoPro 3+ camera.New housing feels flimsy and is rated 20 meter less depth than the previous housing.  I use it for scuba diving so this is a big negative for me.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera...If it worked.
Reviews.Author: tater
Reviews.Content: The problems I have had with this camera are endless:Does not pair with the remote or app, does not allow me to even update the software.  Does not allow me to playback video on my TV, I first must download to my computer and play via HDMI to TV.  Does not show any Wifi network.  To make matters worse, GoPro support is non-existent.  Emailed me to re-install the update software, when I told them that I my camera would not successfully install the update software.  Seriously?  That just makes someone turn on a company, no matter how great their camera design is (it is a great camera, and from the limited videos I've been able to make, this is true.  I wouldn't buy one again until you see more positive reviews.

Reviews.Title: Great camera improved some more.
Reviews.Author: Kevin Quinn
Reviews.Content: Not a huge update from the 3 to the 3+ like how we seen previous models. Think of this like the Iphone 4 and Iphone 4s or the 5 and now 5c & 5S. The now 'old' Hero 3 Black Edition can be had for roughly 70 dollars cheaper currently. So you may want to look into that and picking up an extra battery. It does have better image quality. The big changes are from the casing, which is smaller and lighter, and from the improved battery both of which could easily be upgraded too. Although the lens has been improved the quality of footage from the previous black edition was already excellent so if there is a difference it really is only marginal. The new improved casing doesn't allow you to go as deep in the water as the previous model. But still accepts your Hero 3:BE cases which is a huge plus. As well as let you use the older batteries. Which is always good to have more then just the one. A great sports camera with tight rivals. On the high end for your money but shoots great video with the improved lens and smart phone/tablet app that lets you change setting on the fly easily making the premium price is justified.

Reviews.Title: Great product.
Reviews.Author: skuehnle
Reviews.Content: I've owned my Hero3+ Black Edition for a week and really got to use it in a few situation all in one day.  I mainly use it on fishing/boating trips.  I went out on a boating/fishing trip this past weekend.  I arrived at my location before dawn, so I took some pictures and videos in very low light conditions.  I took several pictures and video on the water.  I am pleasantly surprised with the picture quality/clarity.I've owned GoPro cameras since they first came out.  I've owned 1 original Hero, 2 Hero2 and 2 Hero3 Black Edition cameras.  I use them to video/document severe weather events and fishing/boating trips.  I purchased 1 Hero3 Black Edition and did have the problems many other customers had with their cameras.  I purchased one directly from GoPro and purchased another from Amazon.  GoPro replaced the one directly purchased from them (I got super lucky and the replacement unit worked perfectly).  The one purchased from Amazon worked great right out of the box.  Again, I got very lucky.The quality of the lens has improved drastically over the different models.  Just going from the original Hero to the Hero2, image quality really improved.  I thought the picture clarity/quality was superb with the Hero3 Black Edition....well, the picture clarity resolution has improved with the Hero3+ Black edition over the Hero3 Black Edition.I have taken several videos with the low light option turned on..it is better than the Hero3 Black.  Video quality is less grainy.  IMHO, you can't expect great videos in very low light from a $400 camera, it's just not going to happen.As for the comment on here about the focus is not as good far away as it is close up...the pictures and videos I've taken so far, the focus seems to be about as good as it was with the Hero3 Black Edition.  Once I do more testing I will update on this subject.As for the new Hero3+ housing...well, I can't say that I like the "improved" design. I like that it has a glass lens, but, that is about it.  I don't really like the new style latch.  I'd rather deal with the slightly large housing that has a little extra plastic than use the Hero3+ housing.I guess people who are taking pictures for timelapse use don't mind the longest picture interval is 1 minute.  For me, timelapse intervals of 5 and ten minutes would be great.  I know I can just take a few hundred pictures and go back to delete some of the pictures...but ,that is time consuming.I still need to do testing on the battery and other options.More updates to come with further testing.10/19/13 UpdateI did a lot of comparing photos from my Hero3 BE and this new camera.  The video resolution/clarity is  better at close range but distance focus for pictures and videos is not quiet as sharp...but not nearly a deal breaker as some of the reviews as I've seen.  I've compared videos 1080p from the Hero3 black and Hero3 Plus Black many, many times and I didn't see much (if any) difference.10/21/13 If I could choose 4.5 to 4.8 stars I would...I was never really a fan of any Hero camera for picture taking, I mostly use them for taking videos.  Don't get me wrong, they do take good pictures, I just never really like the fisheye look. For some reason, I don't mind that fisheye look in videos.  I only half agree with the "blurier" focus at longer distances now.  I was able to take some more pictures in different situations and most of them did turn out very good, many of them excellent.  The pictures I took with the earlier review was on a very cloudy,dim day.  The pictures were OK.  This round I took on a better day and more on a nice sunny day.  These pictures couldn't have turned out better.  The jury is still out on the focus issue, but, that would not be a reason not to purchase the camera (for my use anyway).  I just wish they had 12 Meg medium view for pictures.The video quality in all resolutions is better than the Hero3 BE.  I took a few videos in 2.7k resolution and all I can say is WOW.  The resolution is amazing.  It almost looks like you are still there in the moment.Even though the actual battery is a slightly larger mAh battery, it does last longer than the Hero3 BE.Testing the GoPro App, the video preview delay has been cut in half for the Andriod App, but, not so much with the iOS.  Control changes do happen almost instantly.102713 - Update - I should upgrade to 5 stars, but will keep it at 4 stars for now...I've taken at about 30 videos and 50 pictures at different resolutions.  I gotta say that there must be bad cameras being shipped as there was with the original Hero3 Black editions.  I am reading that a few people are having issues with blurry or out of focus pictures.  I gotta say that the majority of my pictures I've taken...couldn't have turned out any better quality.  I still do not like pictures taken with GoPro cameras, but, I cannot knock the image quality.The video quality in any resolution is just amazing...period.  I've taken videos in 720 regular and superview, 1080 regular and superview and 2.7k resolution and the video quality is superb.  The video doesn't look likes it's video, it looks as if you are still there.Most of my videos and pictures are taken during snow and boating/fishing trips.  So far all my videos have been on the water.  The video quality cannot be beaten for a video recorder at this price.I can very well understand the frustration of receiving a products that does work.  I dealt with a Hereo3 Black edition that had a mind of its own.  When it worked, I loved it.  I spent plenty of time pulling my hair out over it not working, but, the videos I got from it when it did work were really good.I'm also impressed with the improved battery life.  I didn't do any exact testing, but I took several videos in 1080 regular, 1080 superview videos and several 10 minutes 720/720 superview videos and still had 2 battery bars left.  Did not charge the battery overnight and the next day took more videos and pictures and never had any battery issues.  That's quite different from how the Hero3 Black Edition was.  I hated the battery life for the Hero3 Black edition.11/06/13This part of the review is more to do with the GoPro App...iOSI installed something call Bluestacks which allows a Mac user to install iOS apps on a Mac.  I do not own a tablet nor do I really want one.  My 13 inch Macbook Pro is portable enough.  Well, I've played around with the iOS version of GoPro App on my Macbook Pro and I must admit I really like it.  My preview works, the only thing I cannot do is playback videos on the Hero3 sd card, but I can view stored pictures.12/21/13 - Still LOVE the camera!

Reviews.Title: Coming from Canon EOS DSLR's this is a Quirky Camera but to my surprise works quite well once you get used to it.
Reviews.Author: salty dawg
Reviews.Content: This is my 1st GoPro so there was a slight learning curve - I have to say this is a troubled product - the GoPro cameras are well built and deliver stunning video in good light (they are not low light cameras)considering their price point and small footprint they have NO Competition as of yet - their history however suggests they have never been bug free and have had numerous glitches over the years - with most resolved via firmware upgrades  - the 3+ Black edition is as all have stated an improvement over the 3 Black edition in the area of battery life, lens capabilities, plus additional frame rates and a new smaller case but overall not much different from the 3 Black and even share the same sensor - with hardware and software experience I can tell you most of the issues with the 3+ are software. This is good news because it's within the realm of the Mfr to resolve.The current firmware version is quite functional but has issues in that it frequently uses timing intervals to resolve functional ambiguity - translation - it's slow to respond so don't hurry the camera when changing modes, or other functions including shutdown and start-ups or you might get into trouble with looping due to inadequate timing code break points designed to resolve nested looping errors - i.e. if you get this camera confused (actually over loaded with executions for the CPU real time available) you will have to take the Battery out to get the camera to function again and most likely will have corrupted the memory to the point that it will require re-formatting before it will read and write.I ran my camera hard after discovering this and could easily create these issues over and over plus many more like the camera not being recognized by my workstation and corrupting the memory card resulting in the loss of all data.Memory - the 3+ is very fussy with the type of memory used especially if you shoot 4K - I suggest the Samsung Electronics 64GB Pro microSDXC Extreme Speed (UHS-1) Class 10... this memory has never given me any trouble but many others have so I stick with it.Having stated these issues, I still rated the camera 4 stars because once you get used to the quirks of the interface it actually works quite well  - be advised though - no matter how skilled you get there will still be those times when you will have to take the battery out or remove the memory card and jack it into an external reader in order to read the memory card or recover control of the camera.One more subject - the lens focus issue - Yup it's true the lens is very sharp in close but goes soft after 10-15 feet and from there out gets worse - in comparison the model 3 Black does NOT DO THIS - so if you are thinking of using this for aerial video - forget it or take your chances that the mfr will fix this.I called the Go Pro customer service before purchasing my unit and the rep that answered said she was not aware of this issue - she then said can you hold I'll ask the tech's - after a few min she returned and told me that they were aware of the problem and working on a SOFTWARE SOLUTION (THE TRUTH SO HELP ME) ... I took them at their word and bought the camera - only time will tell if I made a bad decision because I use it with a DJI Phantom Quad copter.Well if they don't resolve the focus issue I guess I could take up surfing and use it with a 10 foot pole - focus within that range is excellent!UPDATE on Focus Problem with the early Hero 3+ Black cameras *** GoPro is about to release the firmware solution for this issue - preliminary release is herehttps://s3.amazonaws.com/support_upload ... UPDATE.zip

Reviews.Title: Bricked in 5 weeks of Limited Use, Support Slow and Expensive
Reviews.Author: Dutton Peabody, Editor "C D Mann"
Reviews.Content: Save your money.  You might get lucky and get a camera that works.  We thought ours did.  It was great the first 8-10 times we used it.  In the end, we got about 30 seconds worth of usable video and 25 pictures before it became a paperweight.Read the warnings about this and heed them.  I thought that people must be abusing these and that's why they were dying.  Or that people just could not follow instructions.  Not the case.Ours was never dropped or mishandled.  Never used in or near water.  And 5 weeks in we go to turn it on (and it does sometimes turn on) and it won't cycle through modes or take a movie or stills.Sometimes it won't even turn on.We've tried charging.  We've tried swapping batteries.  We even tried the reset we saw in a video on You Tube. (I doubt that this is truly a reset as even for the person demonstrating it, the camera was still doing crazy stuff and/or failing to operate).So far, GoPro is acting like nothing is wrong.  Trust me, something is terribly wrong either in the software or the build quality of the camera.  Or both.  Given the issues with ours, my guess is hardware.  But given the issues I have seen in YouTube videos it could either or both.Four weeks of GoPro support and I am $45 poorer and no nearer a solution.GoPro asserted right away that the problem was most likely not with their camera but with the expensive Sandisk Extreme Micro SD card I was using.  They would not proceed with any troubleshooting until I purchased and tested a new Micro SD card.  Now I have 2 Sandisk Extreme Micro SD cards which work perfectly everywhere except in my GoPro.  A month has gone by and though I am now out the money for a second SD card, I am no closer to a solution.GoPro support is very slow.  They take 3 days to respond to your initial inquiry and every exchange back and forth usually takes another 2-3 days.  Of course, along the way they have you repeat steps you've already tried from viewing their support online and also reading forums and watching other videos from people who have had their GoPro cameras "brick" on them as well.I'm now at a point where I've done everything I can do and GoPro SHOULD be shipping me a new camera.  Instead, they want me to re-format my Micro SD card and try again.  They want me to do this because they do not want to ship me a new camera which will also brick on me and require the same memory reset.  Here are their exact words from an email."However, I don't want you to get a new camera, just to have it give you the same issues which can be corrected with a software re-update and a working SD card."In other words, they know their cameras are prone to bricking and that in some cases reinstalling the software solves the problem.  However, if you will read the other * reviews, you will see that a lot of us have simply been ripped off.  GoPro's support is so slow and expensive that I'm sure most people just give up and throw out their cameras.  Especially if GoPro admits the same thing to them--that these cameras are prone to failure and requiring a re-update of their software.GoPro has one last chance to get this right for me.  They can send me a brand new camera.  I do not want a refurb--that's just a camera that's already proved it was defective.  But my guess is that the best I will get is another broken GoPro that will be prone to the same failures this one was.Stay away.  Save your money.Take a once in a lifetime trip and this thing dies on you on day 2 and you will understand my warning.

Reviews.Title: Out of Focus
Reviews.Author: Chawks
Reviews.Content: Just received my GoPro Hero 3+ today.Unfortunately, it appears that I received a factory defect.  At 1080P video setting, the picture is noticeably worse than my GoPro Hero 2. Less detail and sharpness.Please see the nightstand and leopard painting photos.Update:  For some reason the pictures I placed under customer photos have disappeared.

Reviews.Title: Nothing Close to As Advertised
Reviews.Author: Roger Fox
Reviews.Content: Can't understand why this camera is hailed as so great!The app is pretty cool but has a range of about 20 feet!? The WiFi works but the person who wrote the instructions forgot to mention the camera sets it's own network and cuts off the phone on WiFi! That is, if you depend on your home WiFi to talk on your phone, you are SOL using the app.Battery life is ridiculous! The Blue Shirt at the store told me if I added the Battery Back it would add 4 hours. Wrong! Total battery life with main battery and Battery Back is 1½ hours at 25 degrees ambient.Do you think I got 1½ hours of recording? NO I did not. The recorder automatically shuts off at a prescribed time. I think it's about 30 minutes regardless of battery status. This may be due to WiFi signal. I did notice the signal varies widely and differently from the signal indicator on my device. If that's the case the camera stops recording on signal loss. Ain't that swell?Unless you have better than normal vision you are going to have problems viewing the menu. Low light to read the menu? 4 GIT IT! Wait 'til you wade thru the menu flow chart! Thankfully, I don't drink!The $100 extra for the remote is a WASTE!  You're much, much better off getting a used smart phone, run the GoPro App and control from there.  All the remote does is control the menu, a real live exercise in frustration, turn the camera on and off and start the camera.  App does the same thing and gives you a picture to see . . . so long as you stay within the 20 or so feet which is true with the remote also.It took ONE WHOLE HOUR for my Windows 7 computer to FINALLY recognize the camera to transfer files. And that's after disconnecting virtually every USB device I had connected except the wireless mouse and a half dozen reboots. No exaggeration at all. To add insult to injury you can't move or delete from your computer. Only a very slow copy!  After I got all my USB devices reconnected Windows told me "unable to install USB device" (i.e. camera).The more I type the more I want to take this thing back! A HUGE waste of money!! I can throw away $200 easier than I can throw away $500.UPDATE:  I went on an errand and recorded the 45min trip.  It kept recording but created two files.  I had a auto usb charger plugged in the whole time.  When I turned off the car it kept recording without a hitch, one of few good things I have to say here.  I don't have a lot of confidence it will maintain the battery's charge even while plugged into the USB charger for a longer trip.

Reviews.Title: Not just for sports action: excellent tool for those with disabilities
Reviews.Author: Jerry Saperstein
Reviews.Content: In some ways, the past several years have not been overly kind to me. My sense of balance has been adversely affected and I now need to use assistive devices like canes, trekking poles and rollators (walkers). Other disabilities made it painful to carry the Nikons, Leicas and other cameras I've used over the past six decades as a professional and then hobbyist photographer. Instead I started using point-and-shoot digital cameras and DSLRs, but they presented problems of their own. I figured my days of "street photography", hoping for those candid moments, were over. Wrong. Though intended for recording far more active people and activities than I will ever engage in, the GoPro Hero3+ Black Edition ("BE"), has quickly won a place in my heart.In fact, I love it.The GoPro Hero3+ BE is tiny, light, can be mounted virtually anywhere, has excellent optics, uses powerful CODECS to produce high-quality still and video images, can be controlled remotely with a dedicated remote control or an iOS or Android device. Though it isn't a feature I'll use much, use the proper case and it is water-proof to 131 feet beneath the surface.The range of shooting modes available on the Hero3+ BE is mind-blowing. There are nine video capture modes, four photo resolutions, three continuous photo modes, seven burst photo options (including a staggering 30 photos in 1 second) and seven time lapse intervals.The lens is fixed, but has a wide angle of view. If you've ever done any street photography yourself or are familiar with work of masters like Henri Cartier-Bresson and Robert Frank, you know they generally used lenses between 28 and 50mm. Wide is good. The Hero3+ BE is surprisingly responsive: press the shutter release and you've snapped your picture without major lag.I have to chuckle a bit as I contemplate the coming Chicago winter. I'll be walking the local streets, using a walker to keep me upright, with the GoPro in its waterproof case, the wireless remote in my glove. Set to one of the burst modes, I'm going to be in street photographer's heaven with visions of being revered as the new Cartier-Bresson dancing in my head.The reality is that ordinary people pursuing their ordinary lives is action - just not the kind of action most people rightfully associate with GoPro cameras. It's more modest, but to a guy who despaired of ever again capturing a "decisive moment", as Henri Cartier-Bresson called it, the GoPro is a miracle.Image quality is excellent. No, not as good as the classic Leica, Schneider, Nikkor, Canon and other top-end lenses, but far more than merely adequate. In any event, for the kind of photography I intend to do, content is more important than tack sharpness.Battery life is fine, in my opinion, but it isn't something that really concerns me: I always carry extra batteries. So much better safe than sorry in that regard.Like most people, I hope never to have to need a vendor's tech support, especially in this era of off-shored, script readers who clearly know nothing of the product. I needed GoPro support because of a problem I encountered with the Hero3+ BE WiFi. Color me very, very impressed. The GoPro tech support representative I dealt with was very knowledgeable, listened carefully and, generally speaking, was an absolute pleasure to deal with and, best of all, resolved the issue.I will be adding to this review to cover features that I haven't yet fully explored. Learning al the capabilities of this camera is well worth the investment of time.It should be apparent that I am totally enraptured with the GoPro Hero3+ BE. Performance overall is more than adequate. The low-light capabilities are, frankly, surprisingly good. Yes, the camera has limitatiions - it is not going to replace my Nikons with all their lenses. But the reality is that I can't really carry and usae the Nikons any more and for what I want to capture, the GoPro Hero3+ BE is a miracle machine.Jerry

Reviews.Title: Lemon of a Product, even worse "Customer Service"!
Reviews.Author: Joe Walsh
Reviews.Content: I was very excited after reading the reviews of the Black Edition but found the product and especially GoPro service to be terrible.  I purchased this product on Amazon and after 28 days, still did not have the camera working.  After calling GoPro they first told me I likely had a bad SD card... after which I went out and purchased one off of their approved list.  This did not get the camera working.  After calling back to GoPro I was told that it could be a bad battery and it could take up to 14 days for them to send me another one after I filled out forms for them.  Ridiculous, I just spend $400 for a GoPro to go on a ski vacation... it never worked for the vacation and now after numerous attempts at fixing it GoPro was telling me to fill out more forms and they would do nothing to rush me any parts to repair it.  I expressed my disappointment with buying a product that did not work and getting the absolute run around with customer service (note to GoPro... stand behind your products or your customers will not... have policies that promote taking case of the customer if your products are defective... new net promoter score is below zero in my mind).Don't waste your money on bad products with bad customer service.  I'm glad I purchased through Amazon, they stand behind what they sell and are simply one of the best companies out there.

Reviews.Title: False advertising. Beware!
Reviews.Author: Guillaume
Reviews.Content: As several other reviews mention, the image is actually more blurry in the background. It's a bit like if you have a soft "fog of war" everywhere far.So saying that this camera is sharper than the hero 3 is a huge marketing lie.Furthermore, the smaller housing doesn't make a big difference.I also noted the distorted images on the sides. I'm highly disappointed to have spent that much money in this camera.

Reviews.Title: So far I'm impressed
Reviews.Author: R. Greenlee
Reviews.Content: I purchased my GoPro Silver+ for a few different uses.  I have a DHI Phantom Quadcopter that I wanted to take some aerial footage with.  I'm also a private pilot so I'll be taking video of flights and being in Colorado we ski a lot.  Not extreme skiing but with kids it will be fun to get footage of them and they want to try it out too to film themselves skiing.  We are actually going skiing with it for the first time in about an hour.I was concerned about all the reviews about distance video being very blurry but I'm just not seeing it.  Here is a sample video I took from the quadcopter over Denver.  [...]I'll update more as I get more experience with it and better videos.

Reviews.Title: Great camera with two deal-breaking issues (for me)
Reviews.Author: Relentless "skepticalbeliever"
Reviews.Content: GPH3+ Silver Edition (1.09 firmware):I'm writing this review in a rather disappointed mood. I bought this camera for both action shoots and time-lapse no-scope astro-photography.Some Observations:* The camera is tiny: much smaller and lighter than the pictures would let you believe. It comfortably sits on the palm of your hand.* Wi-Fi is a battery vampire. In my tests, it will cut published battery life in about half. And unless you have the live view BackPack, you are going to need it together with the GoPro app.* Without a heavy investment on accessories/harnesses/handles/leashes, you will find yourself with a $300 paperweight, for all action videography intents and purposes.* The ultra-wide has quite a bit of barrel distortion at the edges, but this is normal for this type of lens.The disappointment:As mentioned above, I had two purposes in mind for this camera: 1) I wanted a good under-water and action/rugged video and still camera to tote along when we go on family trips. 2) I like doing no-scope, time-lapse astrophotography and this is where this camera falls flat on its face. I ran several tests with good light and "night" light. time-lapses of clouds and of stars. And anything out in infinity came very soft, even at the center of the frame. This was a disappointment because my bud's GP2 takes much, much, much better pictures and time lapses than this much newer model. Then as some suggested, I took still pictures of myself and people standing within 10-15 feet were also soft-focused and not in a good way. Another disappointment that I mentioned above is that Wi-Fi will suck the life out of the battery really, really fast. On a full charge, I took about 32 minutes of video and about 17 still pictures before GP3+ battery dies on me.All in all, these issues are simply too important for me and am returning the camera as we speak.

Reviews.Title: Never Worked
Reviews.Author: Mario Marmo
Reviews.Content: I dont know if i had bad luck, but the camera had problems turning on. If it turned on when i inserted the SD card it will automatically turn off. I had big plans with the gopro in my ski vacation. Never worked. I returned it. Be sure you try it before you buy it.

Reviews.Title: Camera freezes constantly - no available information on how to fix
Reviews.Author: Ben
Reviews.Content: I bought the GoPro for my trip to Europe and Southeast Asia. About halfway through the UK trip, the camera started freezing up rendering it useless. The camera boots up properly, but doesn't move through the menu and you cannot record.I've scoured the forums looking for other ways to solve the problem and have updated the firmware to the latest version. It's terribly upsetting that such an expensive product would be so faulty.I'm in Asia now and the only way to get the GoPro to work is manually taking the battery out and putting it back in again. This works about 30% of the time. It doesn't seem to have any logic behind it as sometimes it will work for a few hours, other times it won't.I would have returned the camera for a new one in the given period, but since I'm traveling that option was unavailable. Hopefully when I get back to the States next month, I can work something out with Amazon to get a replacement.When it works, it works great except for low light. However given that it barely works and has ruined the chance for me to record my once in a lifetime trip, I have to give it a one star rating.If you're still looking to purchase one, I'd advise getting it months before your trip and testing it out properly. A lot of these are faulty units.

Reviews.Title: Dead on Arrival - Battery Problems
Reviews.Author: Jeff Garg
Reviews.Content: This company needs to get control of their quality before its too late.Buy one and hope for the best, but if you are buying for a particular event make sure you test it and leave 1 month to resolve quality problems.

Reviews.Title: Awesome action camera!
Reviews.Author: Matt J
Reviews.Content: Awesome camera - amazing HD clarity for POV filming. The underwater video is spectacular - just used it in Maui swimming and snorkeling with turtles and fish and the images are crazy good.The only disappointing thing with GoPro is how they really get you on accessories - you get nothing with the camera purchase and end up spending a lot of money on all the cool accessories and mounts. Just be prepared to double what you spend in accessories.

Reviews.Title: You get what you pay for
Reviews.Author: matthew kowalski
Reviews.Content: The camera is everything it is advertised to be.  Combined with the mobile app, the camera is extremely user friendly.  previewing allows the user to know what will be in the shot vs guess and check.  The silver edition is great as you have many options when it comes to FOV and resolution.  In my opinion, the added cost to upgrade from the white edition is worth it, however, the added options of the black edition aren't necessary unless you are a super techy movie producer or have money burning a hole in your pocket.  overall, I am happy with the silver edition and would highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera
Reviews.Author: John Mitchell
Reviews.Content: I have been been using the Hero 3+ Black edition for a few weeks now, and love the camera. It has worked flawlessly for me, underwater, wifi, etc. I wanted to debunk the lens problem cited by other reviewers -- this lens DOES focus at infinity, near and far are crystal clear. I was concerned about this and my unit has been perfect in this regard. Give it a try -- you'll get shots you never thought possible before!

Reviews.Title: Very Rugged But Loses Points For Image Quality and Issues with GoPro App
Reviews.Author: FirePepper Red "firepepper red"
Reviews.Content: The GoPro Hero 3+ Silver Edition is a very good weatherproof outdoor camera that sacrifices some image quality for its rugged design.  The camera itself is very lightweight and portable almost to the point of feeling like a toy.  Once it is in its waterproof housing it feels more rugged and “professional.”  The image quality is impressive for its small size though it is far behind consumer HD camcorders.  I tried the silver edition which features 1080p at 60 fps.  This allowed for very smooth video with the ability to edit and review the footage with detailed slow motion or frame by frame views.  There were some issues in low light and also with contrast (especially with the auto white balance) but overall the video looks good for a rugged camcorder.One of the touted features of the GoPro Hero is the GoPro App which lets you use your cellphone as a viewfinder for the camcorder via the GoPros built in wifi.  This feature was something I was really looking forward to on this camera but unfortunately  it did not work despite hours of troubleshooting.  I tried a number of solutions including updating the cameras firmware but it would not connect successfully. I even tried different phones (including an iPhone and several Android devices) but it simply did not work.  Many of the user forums also speak about this issue which makes this  a big negative especially considering the price of this device.*** Positive Points: ***- Good (though not great) image quality- Excellent waterproof housing- User replaceable battery- A wide variety of mounts and accessories are available- Bright LED is easy to see (especially underwater)- Decent amount of menu options*** Negative Points: ***- The Wifi feature that connects with the GoPro App did not work despite updating the software- Has some issues with contrast and low light situations- The Menu system takes some time to get used to though the learning curve is fairly simple- LCD screen is small and can be difficult to read especially in low light since the screen is not backlit- It gets very hot (especially in the waterproof housing)- ExpensiveOverall:  The GoPro Hero 3+ is great if you need need to capture video in rugged situations. It loses points for its patchy wifi connectivity with the GoPro App and for its flaws with white balance and low light.  These cannot be overlooked at this price point.

Reviews.Title: Some nice new features, housing seems cheaper, lens not as sharp
Reviews.Author: Richard C. Drew "Anaal Nathra/Uthe vas Bethod...
Reviews.Content: Hero 3+ Black Edition (10/28/2013):I spent last weekend doing some abandoned building exploration and had the Hero3+ Black in tow. Had it mounted to my hard hat most of the time, and handheld for some tighter areas.Low Light: This is important to me, as the places I explore tend to be dark. You have to manually activate the "low light" mode. If you move from dark to light, the light will be briefly blown-out. Moving from light to dark, colors are off for a few seconds. That said, the low light is much better than with previous models. Low light ramps down the FPS. The 4K setting is supposed to have even better low light performance, but I did not try that. If you don't activate the low light setting, the low light performance is the same as the previous model. If you're shooting conditions have a lot of dark to light transitions, I would avoid using this setting. For example, in a dark building where you're walking through pools of bright light, or at night it you wind up shooting into headlights.Smaller and lighter: This applies to the housing only. The Hero 3 housing latch was over-complicated. The Hero3+ is much simpler and more compact - it's obviously much cheaper. The latch is not nearly as heavy duty as on previous models.2x faster - only on the Silver.Faster WiFi and app: I really did not notice a difference. The smartphone app had limited functionality until I removed and replaced the it. Apparently the app does not auto-update. After re-installing everything, the app worked fine. The camera has so many features and functions, you really need to use an app to get the most out of it.  The app is also a great replacement for the LED back - use your smartphone or tablet instead! The default password for wifi is "goprohero".Depth rating has changed: This new housing is waterproof to 40 meters/130 feet (was 60 meters/196 feet). The previous housing (Hero 3) is now called a "dive housing" (optional accessory) and will keep the camera dry down to 60 meters.Lens: I also noticed that objects further than 10' away are not crisp. I wish that this was a setting, or that the Hero had a full manual mode. If you're into selfies or shooting yourself at arms/ski poles/etc. length, this is great.  Want that crisp distance shot? Not so much. For many people, this is a deal killer.

Reviews.Title: Great cam…great fun!
Reviews.Author: Jason Morris
Reviews.Content: I bought these for my students to make documentaries.  They are hardy, easy to use, and very kid-friendly.  Like any new "toy" the fun is with exploring and learning how it works…this was a fun and exciting process for me and my students.  Battery life is more than adequate…especially combined with a back-up battery and charger.  Using the GoPro Studio software, the class is making some pretty cool documentaries.  There are other cams available for such projects, but I wanted a cam that could handle extensive kid use, and was easy to use…the GoPro works!

Reviews.Title: Awesome and better that I thought.
Reviews.Author: Narut Ujnat "Enthusiasm is contagious."
Reviews.Content: I have seen these cameras for a long time, but not purchased one.  However, after seeing some of the videos possible with this camera I purchased the Hero 3: White edition with the new housing.After using this for some weeks, I can say I love this camera and the possibilities.1.: What's in the box?: You receive the camera with the waterproof housing, plus an instruction booklet and a quick start guide.  In addition, you receive a micro-USB cable, plus some mounts and assorted 'thingies.'2.  Aesthetic?:  Well, who really cares how this looks since the point is to capture your desired personal aesthetics!  But, compared to some of the other cameras I have seen, this is a small package, and is cleverly designed.3.  Use?:  The point of the camera is to get it working.  The waterproof casing has been redesigned from the previous model.  It does seem very well-done and is supposedly able to survive to 130 feet.  I have not tested it to any depth with the camera inside.  However, I have taken the housing and placed it under water without a problem.  (I will update this when I get the chance for some waterproof filming).The camera itself has basically three buttons. One for the power/mode, one for the camera to start taking video or pictures (at the top) and a side button which powers wireless.  The wireless function works in conjunction with the App, which I used with an Iphone.  The app is fantastic!  You can control the camera remotely and change the desired function (video, burst, lapse and single pictures, plus whatever function suite the users purposes).  The best thing is the ability to see a preview (except in certain modes like a time-lapse) and the ability to see the pictures and video on the app.  Fantastic.The pictures with the edition I purchased are good, not great, given the 5 MP capability and the close-in build for pictures (I didn't but this to take long-range pictures). However, the video in HD (and this should be changes to 1080 as the default is a bit less) is absolutely gorgeous.  Stunning is the word. The sound is also great, even with the waterproof housing on.  I could still hear myself, others and the sounds of the activity clearly.The wireless function relies on setting up an internal network between your mobile device and the camera, though I did not find this difficult at all.  The only time I had difficulty getting the camera connection was during some very cold weather, and once the camera was warm this went away.  The battery lasts about 2 hours with consistent use, which is pretty good, although I could nurse the camera by turning things on and off when the opportunity present itself.At first, I did not like having to use a micro-SD card, but this is actually okay with an adapter for actual use and allows makes the camera smaller than the previous model.Overall, so far, I am very pleased with the camera and what it allows me to accomplish without too much difficulty.  I suggest that a buyer purchase the grabbag of extra mounts and the lens caps as well.  Great item. Hopefully I do not encounter some of the difficulty that others have had with the camera.  Except for the above, this has not happened!1.  GoPro Grab Bag of Mounts2.  GoPro Protective Lens3.  GoPro Headstrap Mount + Quick Clip

Reviews.Title: Don't forget the accessories
Reviews.Author: Eric G. Hall "fudgypup"
Reviews.Content: I owned a Hero 2 and was surprised to learn I had to buy an SD card separately, so don't forget that.  I'd recommend any class 10 SD card.  Class 10 means it records very quickly.Also, the battery inside the wi-fi remote requires a USB charging cable that is NOT included in the kit.  You need to buy that (~$14) separately too.  The USB charging cable included is for the camera, not the remote.  I just discovered that today (Dec 14) after buying it about four months ago and seeing the low battery warning.  I thought it would take a AAA or watch type batter but no, it's rechargeable.A really cool accessory I'm surprised GoPro doesn't sell their own is a telescoping pole mount.  They feature them in a lot of their videos but don't sell them.  You can get a decent one for as little as $20-$30 but I bought the nice one, a GoPole for about $50.  Really like that thing.

Reviews.Title: Portability!
Reviews.Author: Elliot Knapp
Reviews.Content: I got this camera to use for filming a video of cruising around my city's wilderness park.  After filming a couple of hours of footage, I can say from my first experiences that GoPro's greatest assets are its small size and versatility in terms of mounting.  I was disappointed that the camera doesn't come with a standard tripod mount (or an included SD card, so make note!), but after using it a bit, it becomes obvious that the camera's designed for more extreme filming situations, like being strapped/clipped onto things and going along for the ride.  For this reason, the controls are minimal and the unit operates with the use of only a couple buttons and pretty loud beeps to tell you it's following your instructions (there's no view screen or way to see what you're filming live unless you link the camera to a phone or other mobile device wirelessly)--this basically means you pretty much have to read at least some of the instructions to use the camera effectively.  A pretty big change for me, who's used to using my Canon Rebel for what little video I shoot.  One of the handiest things about the instructions is that they offer recommendations for the quality level you should use for different specific applications, which isn't always the highest quality.  I need to use the camera more to get a better, more well-rounded understanding of its capabilities, but after the filming I've done so far, I'd say this camera won't replace something like a Canon Rebel's (or, of course, an actual digital camcorder designed to specialize in video) ability to view the filming live, adjust zoom, have a slightly nicer mic, etc., but you can certainly put it in situations a regular camera could never withstand.  It all depends what you're planning to use it for!

Reviews.Title: Very good camera, some flaws

} } } Length:: 0:59 MinsI have a GoPro HD HERO (a model first released in 2010) - so the HERO3+ is three models above what I currently have. Most of my review is comparing this with the previous model -- which are *mostly* improvements.I received this camera right after a snorkeling trip to Hawaii, so unfortunately, I was unable to test the HERO3+ underwater. Nonetheless, I put it through the paces in my car and at home to get a feel like what it might be like in more extreme activities outside - biking, go-karting, watersports, etc. The result of that is on this review, though Amazon doesn't support HD video, so you won't get a perfect idea of real world video from the device. After taking a 10 minute video and setting up Wifi, battery life was already below 75%. Perhaps this is because I was playing around with the device setup using more juice, but this doesn't bode well for hours of video at a time without a recharge. Note I used SanDisk Class 10 MicroSD cards to record.With the Wifi features (described in the next paragraph), the total number of buttons on the camera comes to three. It is relatively simple to use the camera, but still requires a bunch of button presses to change settings and you have to get accustomed to pressing which button for the action you want to perform while reading the tiny LCD. Not terribly difficult, but not "Apple simple" either. You've got plenty of options for still photos and multiple video resolutions. I'm happy with close-ups and distance shots -- they seem quite clear at 1080p -- and smoother than the original HD HERO. I didn't try out the 4K -- I don't even have any displays that can support that resolution.All the same accessories that I personally have for my HD HERO -- which the exception of the floaty backdoor (because of a different size camera) -- work with the HERO3+. This edition comes with a wifi remote (which was easy to setup per the instructions) and the ability to access the video and settings with a iOS/Android/Windows mobile device. This makes it MUCH easier to configure the device (rather than via the on-camera menus) and get a quick preview before you get into precarious activities, somewhat negating my previous comments about ease of use. In the box there is also a standard mini-USB charging/sync cord (this really should be micro-USB), another proprietary charging cord (ugh) for the wi-fi remote, instructions, battery, pivot arms/buckles, the camera housing with closed and semi-open cover, and one flat and one curved mount (you'll probably be looking for other mounts after purchase ... for this price I would have hoped GoPro included more.)Unlike the HD HERO which includes component and composite cables, video output options require the purchase of more accessories -- at least a standard micro HDMI will work if you so desire. Behind the removable door (GoPro, why didn't you make this swing open so you don't lose the plastic piece?) is the slot for the MicroSD card and mini USB jack as well. Coming from the HD HERO, I now needed MicroSD cards since the previous model used standard SD cards. Again, not included, so adding to your outright cost if you don't already own.Overall, I dock the camera one star for the lack of accessories and average battery life -- especially given the price. Otherwise I'm very happy with the image quality -- and hopefully the durability during more extreme use of the camera. And if you don't need the super high resolution or perhaps even the wifi remote (the app will still work), the lower cost white or silver editions might suffice for you.

Reviews.Title: Excelent product
Reviews.Author: Langer
Reviews.Content: Yes, it eats batteries a lot ! Already bought a charger with 2 batteries included. The remote control is a plus when traveling.

Reviews.Title: Great, but.............................................
Reviews.Author: Terry Ball
Reviews.Content: Great video recorder. Happy with product.I got this to take pictures of squirrels at my squirrel feeder. The video works great if you use it manually. Set it next to the feeder, set to movie, push the button and walk away.But, then you how a few hours of video tape of an empty feeder that has to be edited. I have tried several video editing software programs and they are all very complicated.So, I went for the burst option which allows you to take 3 pictures in 1 second. The camera itself can be be controlled with an app on the Iphone. The app itself is pretty neat. You can sit nearby out of sight and monitor what the camera sees on the iphone until the perfect picture comes up - then you hit the button. But, a few problems:(1) The WIFI feature will not go through a single pane window. My squirrel feeder is about 25 feet from my dining room. but, there is a window between me and the feeder. The APP loses the camera's WIFI through the window. I have to go outside and sit on the patio in order to be able to manipulate the camera with WIFI.(2) BE careful! From a full charge, when you turn on the WIFI, your battery will go dead in about an hour. They really need to do something about this.But, I am happy with the purchase. Nothing's perfect.And if anyone finds an easy to use video editor, that really IS intuitive, let me know.

Reviews.Title: DOESN'T WORK!!!
Reviews.Author: T. Oakes "Old dude"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera figuring i would by the most expensive gopro to eliminate any issues, boy was i wrongIt has never worked!!!!It is constantly locking up (where you have to pull out the batery to shut it down) or it just shuts off by itself, bought the most expensive gopro recommended micro sd card, no help there. Spent over 8 hours trying to update camera software(firmware) and watched over 15 youtube vidioes (including gopro ones)  just to have the camera inform me to contact go pro service.I could have bought 2 other Hi-def cameras for the cost of this one and they would have worked.Save you money and your time buy something else. Glad I didn't give this headache as a Christmas gift!!!!

Reviews.Title: Completely undependable
Reviews.Author: Arntzville
Reviews.Content: This is by far the least dependable electronic device I have ever purchased. At least 10% of the video files are corrupt and unplayable, it turns off repeatably in the midst of recording for no apparent reason, it goes into error mode and becomes unresponsive often, and removing the battery and memory card do not solve the issues. A terrible purchase in retrospect. I'm shocked that these are so popular.

Reviews.Title: Numerous Focus Problems
Reviews.Author: kblystone
Reviews.Content: Google Hero3+ Focus problems.You can't fix an out of focus lens with a firmware upgrade!  Ridiculous!  That's like saying you can fix a flat tire buy giving the engine a tune-up.  If the lens is out of focus, you have to fix the lens.  Many, many reports of people having problems with the lens.  Beware!

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Little Camera
Reviews.Author: Thomas Grierson
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera at the last minute for a trip to the Galapagos Islands because all of the "serious" dive cameras I was looking at were waaaaay out of my price range.  This camera exceeded any expectations for (1) video quality (I shot the whole trip in 1080p), (2) utility (I also purchase an extender pole that allowed me to take video of myself scuba diving), and (3) reliability (the batteries took a charge quickly and lasted throughout the dives and daily activities - though I did buy back-up batteries because I knew I was likely to be shooting for several hours each day with only an hour or slightly more between dives).  The camera specific WiFi allowed me to review what I had shot each evening without having to link into a larger network (I was outside of the US on a boat without Internet access for 90% of the trip), and was able to share my best shots with fellow divers by downloading them onto their iPads.  UNBELIEVABLE QUALITY for the price.  My friend who brought his "serious" dive camera did not get the quality of shots that I did with my little GoPro Hero 3+ for 1/3 the price.  I recommend this camera to everyone I dive with and can't wait to take it out mountain biking.

Reviews.Title: Great for all situations
Reviews.Author: Andrew Alam
Reviews.Content: I procured my GoPro to use on my paddle board but found so many other uses. The sound capture is really clear with both the skeleton back and the waterproof case. Great to give to children to see the world through their eyes. GoPro has captured some amazing moments with my child that I would have never fathomed capturing without a waterproof case. Stellar buy!

Reviews.Title: Great Camera... What's up with the Battery??
Reviews.Author: Marvelous Marv "big_daddy_marvelous"
Reviews.Content: I used this new cam on a recent trip to the Caribbean.  Pictures are great, but periodically I had to pull the battery because the unit had become unresponsive.  I also felt like the battery life was not great.  Having a second battery handy is advisable... it would have helped me on vacation tremendously.  All other features are great.

Reviews.Title: sometimes when you turn off the camera , you can't turn on again, and you have to remove the battery
Reviews.Author: Rafael Newton
Reviews.Content: sometimes when you turn off the camera , you can't turn on again, and you have to remove the battery

Reviews.Title: Go pro or go home
Reviews.Author: JeffG
Reviews.Content: I bought this edition cause  I wanted all of the gadgets but I didn't realize how awesome this thing is ...its tiny and the video/pics are awesome... my advice is if you get one buy a head strap and extra batteries and a charger . Battery life is only about an hour shooting vid in hd.  So now every where I go I have a gopro mount stuck to it...car, bike living room, my head, dogs head (couldn't get the cat to wear it), kayak, mtn bike.  It comes with a wifi remote so you can control the camera from anywhere or just use your phone to link up with it.  fun but pricey lil toy but screw it I'm worth it.

Reviews.Title: Decent Action Camera, With Some Issues.
Reviews.Author: RLC
Reviews.Content: Compared to the Hero 2 I have this camera has some advantages.First among them is battery life. This is a drastic improvement over my Hero2, even with the battery backpak. It is also a bit smaller and lighter. The lens is a bit of an improvement in areas like near object sharpness. The new video modes for HD don't really impress me as the frame rate drops to get them. I find the color to be superior to the Hero2, it's quite a bit more vivid, without looking fake.  It's also far superior to the Hero2 in low-light shooting. WiFi is an "upgrade" of sorts from the Hero2. It isn't a simple setup and it drains the battery quickly and doesn't have a very long range. The close stills are as good as my HTC phone, not as good as my iPhone 5.  Sound capture was very good, I found it clearer than the Hero2.The major con for me is that objects about 8-10 feet away are blurred. I find this unacceptable for action video as the background is as important to me as the foreground. The still shots suffer from this as would be expected.The camera is constructed every bit as solid as the Hero2. I would still expect to use bacpak batteries for longer shoots.Also, all my shooting was done on fast, high quality class 10 SD cards.  Don't cheap out here or you will definitely be unsatisfied with the video!Overall, it's a decent camera for the price, the blurring of slighlty distant objects may not bother others as it does me, so I can't not recommend it based on that.  The near objects are very crisp.  However, if the budget allows, I would look at the Hero3+ Black Edition and compare.

Reviews.Title: Save $100 and go SILVER instead of BLACK
Reviews.Author: Doug Peterson
Reviews.Content: I bought the Black Edition GoPro based on the fact that it was the "top of the line" of all the GoPro cameras.  I spent some time reading the manual and setting up the camera.  I am really interested in the WiFi setup so that I can view and control the camera remotely.The Black Edition comes with a wireless remote which is linked up to your camera.  However, the Smartphone link-up does the same and much much much more.  So as long as you have a smartphone, save $100 and use that as your remote WiFi link.The other main difference between the Black and the Silver is that the still images can be taken at 12 MP instead of 10 MP - a pretty insignificant difference.Unless you are in a situation where the remote control is much easier to use than a smartphone (android or iPhone), then I would suggest that you go with the Silver Edition which has the same WiFi connectivity as the Black Edition.I considered returning mine after learning about this difference but after spending about 30 minutes trying to figure out how to open the package for my GoPro, I decided that I didn't want to go through that ever again!!!  I many, in fact find some use for the remote control but I definitely see myself using the vastly superior smart phone interface to control this camera.Another point to note - that was not in any of the setup instructions - when linking the GoPro with my Samsung Galaxy S4 I ran into a problem.  The network settings were not linking because of a default Advanced setting on my phone.  To remedy this, I went to Wifi-networks, click the menu button to the left of the home button on the bottom of the phone, click Advanced when the popup window comes up, then go to "Auto network switch" and deselect this option.After doing this my phone immediately connected to the GoPro following the instructions from GoPro.  The downfall to deselecting this option is obvious - the phone will automatically switch from one network to another for WiFi service when needed.  So you may have to do some manual switching.Hope this helps someone else having the same issues.  If you end up saving $100 by going for the SILVER as a result of my review, send me $1 on paypal and after I make my hundred back I'll amend this review.  Send to: ty at sportcow and then a dot com.  I'm sure Amazon has some rules against posting stuff.  Ha!  We'll see if that works.

Reviews.Title: A nice step up
Reviews.Author: G. B. Keefer "Star Wars freak"
Reviews.Content: Having owned all the various GoPros back to the Hero HD1 I can say that this is by far the best one yet. I had previously owned the Hero 3 and ended up getting rid of it after a couple of months of frustration with it, primarily with the too short battery life. It held great promise with the WiFi integration and the remote as well as the iPhone app giving even greater control. I found the remote to be basically worthless as the wifi put an even greater strain on the already short battery life. Even with the add on battery backpac I was only able to get around 90 minutes of use. Also the remote was not anywhere near as up to the challenges of the camera itself,  after the second replacement I gave it up for good and went back to my previous method of just shooting non stop and cutting everything in editing, more work for me on the backside that I had hoped the remote would streamline. Even then I was missing half my action in the water (I use mine on the deck of my surfboard) to the battery life.But this review is about the new Hero3+. Happy to say the battery life is greatly improved. I'm getting a solid 2 hours+ with just the onboard battery now. I like the smaller frame, though the change means this is the first version that needed a different back door for the add ons. A back door which is still not widely available currently.  I have not tried the remote and don't plan to, I'll still hit start before I paddle out and then chop out the good stuff in editing. This has been made incredibly easy using the updated FREE software from GoPro, Cineform Studio. It makes it a breeze to just cut out the fun clips from the chaff and then knit them together into short videos with musical accompaniment.  The software also allows you to add some basic filters as well as more advanced in software edits to the speed and even framing within the shot. You can even add keyframed zooms which really gives you a lot of control of what was basically a static framed shot.In short, I'm very satisfied with this iteration of the GoPro camera and finally decided to let go of my trusty GoPro Hero2! I look forward to being able to tack on a battery backpac in the near future for even greater freedom.

Reviews.Title: Total reap off
Reviews.Author: Leon Herce
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for scuba diving and had it shipped to Thailand, paying import duties and shipment. The plan was to take to Maldives, small and cute stuff. After a few shots, it started freezing - when diving, it froze in 90% of the ocassions, so spoiling all the fun in Maldives, big frustation and big disappointment.I tried everything when I was back home, different SDs (I bought it also from goPro btw), all possible ways of updating the firmware... I spent hours with customer service (which happens to be horrible: messy and unreliable) ... anyway I had to ship it back to the US after 40 days of frustration, again paying shipment !I have seen on the internet  that they still have not found a fix. all in all, a shame

Reviews.Title: Short focus and proprietary mounting options
Reviews.Author: S. D. Johnson
Reviews.Content: In reviewing the Hero 3+ I have found that no matter the resolution, and no matter the WB nor adjustments I make I cannot get the camera to focus properly. I have taken video with the unit mounted onto my roll bar in my Miata, and the unit has perfect focus on the dash, but is very blurry out the windshield. It likes to also focus on spots on the windshield as well.Going through the features, I have found that the new Superview feature makes for shooting in 1080p and above a better experience. The Superview helps alleviate some of the fish-eye effect from the lens and the unit performs much better overall under different lighting conditions.The WiFi app was fine, as well as the WiFi remote.
