Reviews.Title: In Summary: Great choice if you need it to be super light and mountable. There are sacrifices...
Reviews.Author: Super Mum
Reviews.Content: The GoPro Hero has been marketed as the ultimate adventure camera. It can handle surfing, scuba, snowboarding, and extreme conditions.  It is lightweight and itty bitty so it can easily be mounted to a surfboard, helmet or your body without weighing you down.  It does work well in these conditions (well, we don't do snow but we have used it in every other condition).Our family has another shockproof/waterproof/etc. camera and these are thing things I am not as fond of with the Hero3+ Silver:  -  No zoom.  Usually "entry level" waterproof cameras don't have optical zoom but most typically have digital zoom.  Yes, digital zoom isn't amazing but the option should at least be there to get a better shot of the subject matter.  Often times I had too much landscape and not enough of the object I was hoping to capture.  This can also make for a less focused picture on the desired target.  -  Pieces!  My other camera has a battery door that is connected, it also has a door for the charging port that is connected.  The Hero3+ has neither.  The teeny tiny little pieces of plastic are hard to find and the charging door must be removed during charging or hooking up to a computer.  I haven't lost one permanently YET. I'm sure it is only a matter of time. I spent a good half hour looking for the charging door the other day.  -  This is a small complaint as it seems most electronic manufacturers are going this way but it does not come with an AC adapter. It comes with a USB cord that can be plugged into a computer but you will have to swipe an AC adapter from another company that didn't try to save a couple of bucks.  -  No screen to view photos.  I'm torn about this one.  A screen would likely increase the size of the camera thus making it less "mountable." However, when snorkeling, scuba diving, floating down a river, etc. I often like to check the photo to make sure I got the whole fish/turtle/group on inner tubes  in the shot.  I would recommend not using this camera for the first time during something extremely important to you (your first dive in Hawaii).  Play with it first. Get to know it.  Be cognizant of how much it captures (width/height).  Play with how you hold it or where you mount it to determine how you need to position your body/arm to capture the photo/video you want.  -  Battery does not last nearly as long as my other camera. I usually get around an hour of constant use.The upside to the Hero3+ Silver:  -  Size. As mentioned before, its size is what makes it mountable on just about anything.  -  Wide angle lens captures a great amount of the landscape (though see no-zoom above... sometimes too much landscape and not enough of the subject).  -  App works flawlessly.  My other waterproof/shockproof camera did not have onboard WiFi and I remedied this with a EyeFi.  It was always dropping connection and never seemed to want to transfer when I needed it to.  Not having to rely on a third party app and hardware is nice.  -  Mounting options. There are a ton of great accessories (sold separately) for this product that truly make it versatile to whatever your needs are.  -  Waterproof up to 131'.  My other camera does not have the ability to go this deep and I can only use it for shore dives, surfing, snorkeling and the pool.  This camera allows me greater versatility.*Word of caution as the holidays are coming up.  The camera uses a MICRO SD card (not a regular SD).  Many people don't have these floating around their home and you should consider purchasing a Micro SD (must be "Class 10" to be compatible) so they can play with it as soon as it is unwrapped.

Reviews.Title: The GoPro HERO3+ Camera Black Edition ROCKS!
Reviews.Author: Diana De Avila "MS Gkygrl"
Reviews.Content: The Black edition of the GoPro Hero3+ is the top of the line camera from GoPro.  It boasts several  ultra-high-resolution capture modes and high frame rates for standard HD resolutions; burst speeds for still photos has been greatly improved in this iteration.My impressions of the GoPro Hero3+ are:- small form-factor- lots of mounting flexibility included.  But for more, I purchased the GoPro Head Strap Mount- very few controls.  Using sub-menus takes a little getting used to, but toggling between menus is doable.The small form factor - which is smaller than previous models - consolidates inputs and outputs down to two ports and a SD card slot.  On either side of the Hero3, you'll find a small pinhole microphone for audio recording alongside your video. GoPro claims that its wind reduction algorithms have been improved for this generation. Like the previous generation, the camera comes with a swappable Skeleton back panel for its clear plastic case that can be used to further improve audio quality at speeds below 100 mph at the expense of waterproofing.One of the negative issues I found (and it is a little picky) has to do with form factor and the door that covers the ports.  It is not attached in any way and would be easy to lose - especially given the fact that this is a camera for sports of all kinds.Overall a wonderful camera that can be mounted in various ways.  It provides ease and flexibility for those who want to film fishing, water sports, snow sports or just want to enjoy a mounted camera out in the wilderness.  There are so many different uses for it.  I look forward to really venturing out with it!5 stars for fun, ease of use and form-factor.

Reviews.Title: Shaky piece of junk
Reviews.Author: Don
Reviews.Content: I mounted this over-priced battery-sucking piece of junk to the windshield of my CJ7.  I ran it off-road in both rough bouncy rocks and in nice baby-butt smooth sand and the images looked like I was driving on the San Andreas during The Big One.  I then took it on a nice flat level asphalt highway and that reduced the shake to a 9.0 Richter or so.  Unwatchable? Well, not quite, because I did watch the vids for a few moments.  I then took about 10 minutes of night driving where the only illumination was my Jeep's head lamps.  Nice.  It was so dark I couldn't see squat and therefore couldn't really detect any shake.  Pairing the GoPro to your phone works pretty well but sucks the life outta the GoPro's battery like a bad marriage.  Thank gawd I used AmEx points to pay for this little blunder of technology.  I'd hate to think I spent any real money on it.

Reviews.Title: Best Got Better
Reviews.Author: E. Byers
Reviews.Content: GoPro decided to take the best action camera out there, and instead of totally revamping it, improve on some of the issues.The rundown, this assumes you are familiar with the standard GoPro Hero3 Black Edition (non +).* Better battery -- This has been a big one, and it's not a huge jump, but considering the ~1.5 hours on the original, this one gets you a lot closer to 2 hours.  Huge bump on this one.  Achieved mostly by software/hardware optimizations I believe, battery is the same physical size, mAh is up about 130 (from 1050 to 1180 I believe).* Faster wifi, supporting a new standard (theoretically 4x faster), and better range.* SuperView mode.  This is basically something that you could do manually in post, but now the camera gives you the ability to do it right on camera.  Basically uses all available pixels, and while it seems like a gimmick, it's really quite awesome in practice.  For users like me who don't do much post processing, this is great.* Better lens, supposedly 33% less distortion.* Size.  This is the most noticeable, size and weight get dropped 20%.  However this is almost completely in the case.  Case is completely redesigned, much sleeker.  Accessories that use the case or need a case extension, if you already own these you'll have to buy the pieces to go with it (or drop your Hero3+ in the old case), and I believe most new accessories will comes with pieces for both (for instance the new go pro caps and lids comes with a lid that fits both).  The waterproof rating went down, but I believe it's in the 200-300 foot range, and if that's an issue, again you can use the old case. (As a side note you cannot use the old camera in the smaller case as there is a notch in the lens area that prevents this.  I assume because of field of view being blocked by the smaller opening, and the old one not being optimized for it, you could push it in there...but they put the notch there for a reason.Overall its a small incremental improvement.  This may come at a disappointment to some, but it continues making the camera great, knocking away issues that people had.  It remains the best camera for a reason, and this update makes sure it stays there for a little bit longer.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera but...
Reviews.Author: smartydog904 "bluedog"
Reviews.Content: This thing is so small without the case wow! But mine also is very hot after use, but it has worked every time. My issue is with the thumb screw, too big and clunky, hard to tighten up once it's on my helmet the screw is so close to the camera body and the helmet it's hard to get it to tighten up. Should have made it a flat or wing nut style. The other issue I wish it had a zoom button. I spotted this really cool leaf bug out on the trail but couldn't get close enough to it to have it show up on video without scaring it away! Would be great to have a zoom button in the online controls. How about a warning beep if mud or anything blocks the screen?? Never thought to keep checking it during fun times for mud on screen, mostly due to being new with it. What a disappointment to find a glob of mud got on camera during a dangerous ride and it effected the video quality. Just some food for thought for GoPro. The camera it self is great, love it, works fine but don't think it's any better quality than my Contour roam 1st generation, same video quality, but the Wi-Fi ability pushed it to the top. The Contour you have to have a computer with you to be able to see video or wait till you get home. That's the feature that sold me on the GoPro to be able to instantly view my video on my iphone right after the ride! Too COOL! Yeah battery life sucks, so make sure you have at least 2 extra as well as extra sd cards. The large field of view does take in quite a lot of your environment but on the bike trail it doesn't due justice to the large rocks and roots you jump over due to camera taking in everything in your view. When looking down at the rocks it seems like there farther away than they are? Just some nit picky things I noticed. Don't get me wrong this camera goes out the door with me on every trip! It's worth the sale price for sure, I am wondering if it will melt the case on extended use, say all day. Or if the heat will effect the images or corrupt the video or the circuitry inside. Guess I'll find out...Bottom line: some cool features, small footprint, waterproof case, can be pricey so watch for sales. Great little companion to capture those cool expeditions!!!

Reviews.Title: Are you contemplating Hero3 vs Hero3+ ? ... choose the Hero3+.
Reviews.Author: D. Truong "El Duke"
Reviews.Content: This GoPro Hero3+ HD camcorder is an amazing portable video camcorder.  It's hard to say something about this product that hasn't already been said by another reviewer.  However, if you are currently contemplating buying either this or the regular GoPro Hero3 Black Edition... I would definitely buy this one over the older version. The main reason being that the older version had horrible battery life.  This newer upgraded version has 30% better battery life and is 20% smaller.  Also, some people had complained about blurry video quality of the older Hero3 and I noticed this one advertises it to have 33% improved sharpness/image quality. This also lends to my belief that they made this version to fix the shortcoming of the older Hero3. I think these improvements alone is worth the added price...although I think that they should have just replaced the older GoPro Hero3 with this version instead of still selling both of them.  I mean, they should have just discontinued the older Hero3 and sold this one at the same price as the older Hero3.

Reviews.Title: A hypothesis at best...
Reviews.Author: T. McIntosh
Reviews.Content: Waited and saved for a this... all I can say is that I've never been so disappointed by a photo related product. It's a nice sounding hypothesis with some sort of voodoo marketing magic, but the product itself is a joke that costs 10x its worth... wow, it's bad!Some highlights:-WiFi didn't give me a live view ("preview") out of the box, so I updated the firmware (and WiFi settings 3 times) which promptly made the WiFi stop working while the camera was on all together. (strangely WiFI can be left on even though the camera is off, which promptly drains the battery in under 10 minutes)- WIth WiFi on and camera on, the battery last about 15 minutes.-With WiFi on the battery heats up the camera in about 5 minutes to the point of being hot. I'm no expert, but sounds like a problem to me.- Turning the camera and wifi on and off isn't trivial. Since the buttons are used for various things you have to either try a few times and cycle through everything, or time how long you hold them to a fraction of a second.- Image quality is poor (My phone does as well) and having to correct for the ridiculous fisheye effect on a PC only adds additional time and effort, and reduces the quality more.- No view screen, so, there is no way to frame image without WiFi (if you can get it working and aren't dropped b/c of noise) or HDMI wires (Not water proof anymore). I suppose this doesn't matter because of the fisheye view. Basically it is useless as a camera in this sense. You get what it delivers and thats it.- No usable sound with case on; no way to mount it without case. No way to plug in a good mic.-Micro SD card capacity choices are small. Record times are short.

It has no viewfinder so you only know how the shot was framed after you download it.  It has poor sensitivity to room light and seems designed mostly for outdoor use.  It has no zoom or focal capacity so, like the old fashioned Kodak brownies, you get a fixed focal range.  It has two wide angle settings which offer a kind of "gee-whiz" factor but it looks as though it would produce an effective image only at fairly close range.  Great camera to give your teenager to shoot pictures of his buddies skate boarding, but not much else.
